narrative_nodes.text: Welcome to a choose-your-own-adventure game made by Carl, where you get to have fun (hopefully) and also learn some chemistry along the way (also hopefully)! -- For a tutorial or information on formatting your answers, type 'help'. If this is your first time, check out the tutorial before moving on. -- You can find the GitHub repository for this app at https://github.com/OrigamiKoala/chem-text-adventure -- It would be greatly appreciated if you could take a minute to fill out a super short feedback form. Thank you so much! -- Type anything to begin.

And that is where the story ends...for now. Check back in a couple days and there might be something new :) -- Check out GitHub repository for this app at https://github.com/OrigamiKoala/chem-text-adventure -- All of the activities can be found here -- Interested in chemistry? Check out:
  • Cartoon Guide to Chemistry
  • Khan Academy's Chemistry courses
  • Chemistry by Steven S. Zumdahl
  • Chemical Principles by Steven S. Zumdahl
  • Atkins' Chemical Principles by Peter Atkins
  • Atkins' Physical Chemistry by Peter Atkins
  • Inorganic Chemistry by Gary L. Miessler
  • Organic Chemistry by David Klein
  • Organic Chemistry by Jonathan Clayden
-- It would be greatly appreciated if you could take a minute to fill out a super short feedback form. Thank you so much!
Sorry, that section does not exist yet.

Alright, I know you're disoriented, so stay with me here. You've just woken up in a dark room - perhaps a jail cell of some sort? You don't remember how you got here. -- What do you do? (Type the number of your answer, or your answer character for character) --
  1. Get up
  2. Look around

As you struggle to stand up, you notice your hands and arms feel numb - you can't move them well, and you're pretty uncoordinated. But you still manage to struggle to your feet. What do you do next? --
  1. Look around
  2. Examine your hands and arms

Looking around, you see you are in a pretty small room, perhaps a 15 foot cube? The lack of light makes it difficult to see much. On your left is a wooden door. In front of you are three...what looks like hazmat suits? Something like that. Your arms feel numb. What do you examine next? --
  1. Your hands/arms
  2. The suits
  3. The door

Looking down at your hands and arms, you notice they are covered in what looks and feels to be huge bug bites, but it's hard to tell in this dim light. You are wearing a hazmat suit too, but that doesn't seem to prevent you from being bitten. As you look at your arms, you suddenly feel a bite, and the area around the bite immediately goes numb. What do you do next? --
  1. Examine the suits
  2. Examine the door

The three suits in front of you are white, as is the suit you are wearing. These suits cover the body from head to toe, leaving no area unexposed. Upon closer inspection, you notice that the three of the four suits each have different size holes - the one you are wearing has the largest holes, which are still pretty small. The suit on the right seems to have no holes whatsoever. -- Each suit has a label on it - the one you are wearing has "0.5 mm" written on it. -- The one on the left has "10 \(\mu\)m" written on it. -- The one in the middle has "1 \(\mu\)m" written on it. -- The one on the right is labeled "0.01 nm". -- What do you do next? --
  1. Examine your hands and arms
  2. Examine the door
  3. Figure out what suit to put on

The door on your left looks to be made of pretty solid wood. It has an ornate, slightly tarnished silver handle, which you try to turn, but can't. You don't see the actual lock, though. But as you push against the door, the lock feels like a sliding bolt. However, it isn't budging. -- What do you do next? --
  1. Examine your hands and arms
  2. Examine the suits
  3. Try to force the door open
  4. Try some other way to open the door

These suits seem to be meant to protect you from the flies that are biting you. But you don't know how small the flies are, so you need an estimate. You try hard to think of the smallest fly you've ever seen. About how big was it? --
  1. 1 cm across
  2. 1 mm across
  3. 1 \(\mu\)m across
  4. 1 nm across

But how small can a fly get? Can a fly get infinitely small? --
  1. Yes
  2. No

Well, let's test out this theory if things can be infinitely small.
--
To test this out, grab a piece of paper and tear it in half. Then tear each piece into smaller pieces, and repeat until you can't anymore.
--
Was it easier to tear the large pieces, or the smaller pieces?
narrative_nodes.next: is it possible to tear forever

narrative_nodes.text:
Well, a fly must be made of something, right? And at some point, you have to reach the smallest thing in existence, right?
--
To test this out, grab a piece of paper and tear it in half. Then tear each piece into smaller pieces, and repeat until you can't anymore.
--
Was it easier to tear the large pieces, or the smaller pieces?
narrative_nodes.next: is it possible to tear forever

narrative_nodes.id: is it possible to tear forever
narrative_nodes.text:
So, if it takes more and more energy to tear the paper into smaller and smaller pieces, is it possible to tear it into smaller pieces forever? --
  1. Yes
  2. No

Yeah. At some point, you have to reach the smallest thing - and the fly can't be smaller than that. This smallest thing is called an atom, which is about 0.1-0.5 nm in size. So what suit should you put on? --
  1. The leftmost one
  2. The middle one
  3. The rightmost one
  4. Keep your current suit on

As soon as you put on this new suit, the biting seems to stop. Hooray! -- What do you do next? --
  1. Try to open the door
  2. Try on a different suit
Unfortunately, you still feel the bites of bugs. As they continue to bite you, your arms feel weaker and weaker.

You know the sliding bolt is probably metal, so maybe you might want to try using magnets to open the door? -- What would you like to do next? --
  1. Try to force the door open
  2. Try to find a magnet
You brace your legs and push on the door as hard as you can.

When you push with all your might, you at first feel a hard resistance. But, slowly yet surely, the door begins to give way. Emboldened, you push even harder, past your limits...and then with a loud SNAP! something breaks. -- You push on the door again, and it falls over, spraying wood splinters all over you. -- You carefully step over the remains of the door and look around. -- Type anything to continue.

Unfortunately, despite your best efforts, the door does not give way. You think maybe you should find a magnet, which could help you move the metal sliding bolt and unlock the door. -- As you search around the room for a magnet, your eyes land on one of the suits. It has an ID card sewn into it. -- You grab the suit and rip the ID card out. However, in the process, you accidentally shatter the very fragile ID card. What do you do? --
  1. Attempt to unlock the door with a shard of the ID card
  2. Try to find another way to unlock the door

You pick up the largest shard of the ID card, wondering if it is large enough to have a strong enough magnetic pull to open the door. You approach the door and place the shard where the bolt is. -- Unfortunately, the shard of the ID card doesn't seem to pull strong enough to move the bolt and unlock the door. -- What do you do next? --
  1. Try to force the door
  2. Find another way

You realize that maybe you could use the ID card from another suit. You walk back to the suits and try to gently remove one of the ID cards without breaking it.
<script>pickup("ID card")</script>

You succeed in extracting the ID card from the suit without damaging it. You rush back to the door, and place the ID card where you think the bolt should go. You wiggle it around a little bit, trying to get the ID card to snap to the bolt.

Unfortunately, you do not succeed in removing the ID card without damaging it. -- What do you do next? --
  1. Try to force the door
  2. Try to remove another ID card
  3. Try to use multiple shattered pieces

That still doesn't seem to be strong enough. -- What do you do next? --
  1. Try to force the door
  2. Remove another ID card and use both cards
  3. Use the ID card and some other shards
You hold up a pile of ID card material to the door, and try again to move the bolt.

Finally, your attempts to open the door yield fruit. Carefully, you use your magnet to slide the bolt, and excitedly you grab on the door handle. It turns!
--
Why do you think that worked? Why didn't using the original shard work?

The fact that more ID card material meant a stronger pull implies that the ID card was made of lots of tiny little magnets. As it turns out, these tiny little magnets are the atoms you learned about earlier! -- So which of the following do those atoms have? --
  1. Positive parts
  2. Negative parts
  3. Both

That's right! -- The positive parts are called protons, and the negative parts are called electrons. (There is also a neutral part called a neutron). The protons and electrons exert magnetic fields that interacted with the bolt. The more atoms, the more magnetic fields, and the stronger the pull, so the easier it was to move the bolt. -- There are different types of atoms, called elements, each with a different number of protons. A bunch of ata about the elements are displayed in the Periodic Table of the Elements -- ptable.com -- Each element has a symbol (eg "H" for "hydrogen") and an atomic number - the number of protons (the number on top of the symbol). -- In the future, type 'periodic table' to summon the periodic table. -- You step outside your cell. -- Type anything to continue.

You enter yet another small, dark room, and see a desk on your left in the dim light. There is yet another door in front of you. -- What do you do? --
  1. Examine desk
  2. Examine door

When you get closer to the desk, you see the faint outline of a lamp, and something else on the table. The desk feels to be made of solid wood. There are no drawers. -- What do you do next? --
  1. Turn on the lamp
  2. Examine the door

This door appears to be made of solid metal. It is freezing to the touch. There is no door handle, but there is a number keypad. When you push on the door, it doesn't budge at all. This does not feel like a door you could shove open. -- What do you do next? --
  1. Examine the desk
  2. Use your magnet on the lock

Once again, you hold your pile of ID card material next to where you think the lock is. But the material just sticks to the metal, and you find it difficult to remove. -- You don't think you can open the bolt using magnets this time; the metal door is magnetic, and is interfering. -- What do you do next? --
  1. Examine the desk
  2. Examine the door

You flick the switch, and the lamp sputters on. It flickers, but in the new light you can see the other object on the table - what looks to be a small, but powerful, stun gun. You pick up the stun gun and put it in your pocket. -- What would you like to do next?
  1. Examine the door
  2. Try to use the stun gun on the door's keypad to fry it

Perhaps you could use the stun gun to fry the circuits in the keypad and unlock the door?
--
You take out the stun gun from your pocket, but find it is covered with the ID material. When you remove the ID material, it suddenly flies out of your hands and sticks to the wall on your left.
<script>removeInventory("ID shards", "all"); removeInventory("ID card", "all")</script>
--
Why did it do that? The ID card isn't a strong enough magnet to literally fly out of your hands.

The ID material is not a strong enough magnet to do that, which means the wall to your left must also be a magnet. -- What do you do? --
  1. Shoot a beam of electricity at the keypad from a distance (to prevent electrocution)
  2. Shoot a beam of electricity at the keypad close up (risk of electrocution)

You take aim at the keypad and attempt to shoot a beam of electricity at it. -- But the beam curves away from the keypad, towards the wall. -- Knowing that the wall has its positive end facing you, is the beam:
  1. positive
  2. negative
  3. neutral
narrative_nodes.hint: If the beam was positive, would it be attracted to or repelled by the positive wall? If it were neutral, would it be attracted or repelled at all?

narrative_nodes.text:
You walk closer to the keypad and take aim. -- But when you fire, you notice the beam strikes the area just to the left of the keypad, closer to the magnetic wall. -- Knowing the wall has its positive end facing you, is the beam:
  1. positive
  2. negative
  3. neutral
narrative_nodes.hint: If the beam was positive, would it be attracted to or repelled by the positive wall? If it were neutral, would it be attracted or repelled at all?

narrative_nodes.text:
That's right! -- So the beam is made of:
  1. protons
  2. electrons
  3. neutrons

Nice! -- The beam of electricity is made of electrons. -- What do you do next? --
  1. Get super close to the keypad and electrify it
  2. Retrieve your ID material and try to unlock the door with the magnets

You get right up in front of the keypad and fire the stun gun.
--
You feel a slight crackle as a little bit of the electricity hits you and races across your skin. Your hands and arms go slightly numb.
<script>changeHP(-5)</script>
--
However, the keypad flashes, and then shuts off. You hear a faint click.
--
Why did the electricity pass through your body instead of being attracted to all the atoms in your body?

The beam must have knocked electrons out of the atoms in your body and replaced them, keeping the beam going. -- However, the beam was negative, not neutral. So did it contain any protons? --
  1. Yes
  2. No
Why did the beam knock out electrons but not protons?

Since the beam knocked out only electrons, that must mean the protons were all clumped together in a group, and the electrons were floating around. -- Knowing that positive and negative parts attract, the electrons must:
  1. Float around randomly
  2. Orbit around the protons
That's right! -- The protons are bundled together in the nucleus of the atom (in the center), and the electrons orbit around the nucleus. -- What would happen if the beam had neutrons in it?

If the beam had neutrons, part of it would be attracted to the wall and the other part would keep racing towards the keypad. -- Did that happen? --
  1. Yes
  2. No

Exactly. So did the beam have neutrons? --
  1. Yes
  2. No
So where in the atom would the neutrons be?

The neutrons must also be bundled in the center of the atom with the protons.
--
Is it easier for the beam to knock out the electrons 'farthest' from the nucleus, or 'closest'? Remember that the nucleus pulls on the electrons, and pulls harder on closer ones.
narrative_nodes.next: farther or closer higher or lower electrons

narrative_nodes.id: farther or closer higher or lower electrons
narrative_nodes.text:
That's right!
--
So do the electrons farthest from the nucleus have 'more' or 'less' energy than those closest to the nucleus?

Nice. -- The electrons with the highest energy (farthest from the nucleus) are called valence electrons. -- The electrons have different energy levels, called orbitals -- When you push on the door, it slowly swings open, and (at long last) you step foot outside your cell. -- Type anything to continue.

You step into a dimly lit lab, with equipment scattered all over the place. Only two of the lightbulbs seem to work, and they occasionally flicker. In the dim light, you can see a lab table in front of you, and a counter behind that. On the table in front of you is a large machine. On the counter are all sorts of chemical equipment - vials, beakes, flasks, eyedroppers, and much more. There are two beakers with pieces of metal inside, connected by a wire - some sort of lab setup? To the left of the sink is a fume hood.There is also a large book on the right of the sink. There is a row of cabinets above the counter. -- What do you examine? --
  1. The machine on the table
  2. The cabinets
  3. The book
  4. The lab setup

You approach the machine on the table in the center of the room. It is a huge beast that looks something like a large printer. There is a small screen, which is currently off. -- What do you do? --
  1. Turn on the machine
  2. Examine the cabinets
  3. Read the book
  4. Investigate the lab setup

The five cabinets above the counter are made of polished wood, with brass handles. You open the one on the left, and see rows and rows of vials. Each vial is labeled in careful handwriting. Some contain powders; other, liquids. On the bottom row is a bunch of metal canisters, also labeled. The next two cabinets down the row are also filled with vials. -- You open another cabinet, and see a whole bunch of empty glassware, spoons, eyedroppers, and a large scale. -- You open the rightmost cabinet. This one appears to be a small library of sorts - it is stocked with all sorts of books. -- What would you like to do? --
  1. Examine the machine on the table
  2. Open one of the metal canisters
  3. Read the book on the counter
  4. Investigate the lab setup

When you get closer to the book, you see it isn't really a bound book, more like a looseleaf collection of papers held in a worn leather sheath. -- You open it up, and see the first page appears to be lab notes for some sort of experiment creating a chemical called hydorcortisone. The next page appears to also be lab notes, on how to make amoxicillin. -- After looking at the next few pages, which are all similar, you can tell this book is the lab notes of some chemist, on how to create all sorts of chemicals. -- What do you do next? --
  1. Examine the machine on the table
  2. Examine the cabinets
  3. Investigate the lab setup

On the countertop are two beakers, each with a piece of metal stuck in it. The pieces of metal are connected by a wire, with a lightbulb attached. The lightbulb flickers. -- -- Since the lightbulb is lighting up, what must be running through the wires?

That's right!
--
But how does it work?
--
If electrons are flowing from the left side to the right, do the atoms on the right side pull 'more' or 'less' on the electrons?

Yep. -- So not all atoms pull on electrons with equal strength. -- The atoms on the right side, since they pull harder on the electrons, are more electronegative and have a higher electronegativity. -- As you examine the lab setup, the stun gun in your pocket beeps. You take it out, and notice it is flashing a low battery image. -- What would you like to do next? --
  1. Examine the machine on the table
  2. Examine the cabinets
  3. Read the book
  4. Attempt to charge the stun gun

You press the red power button next to the screen, and a loading screen pops up. The machine begins whirring loudly. When it finishes booting, the screen displays "Insert sample". -- You can put anything in your inventory into this machine, while it is on, by right-clicking on the item. -- What would you like to do next? --
  1. Examine the cabinets
  2. Read the book
  3. Investigate the lab setup

You take down one of the white metal canisters. -- -- You twist open the silver valve on top, and hear a hiss as red gas begins to flow out. -- The gas smells weird, so you quickly close the valve and put the canister back. -- What would you like to do next? --
  1. Examine the machine on the table
  2. Read the book
  3. Investigate the lab setup

You decide to try to harness the flow of electricity to charge your stun gun, instead of powering a lightbulb. -- Carefully, using some plastic tweezers, you take the lightbulb off the wires, and it goes dark. -- You take the batteries out of your stun gun, and attach the wires to the ends of the batteries. -- Charging the battery will take a while. What would you like to do in the meantime? --
  1. Examine the machine on the table
  2. Open the cabinets
  3. Read the book
  4. Take a nap

You approach the machine on the table in the center of the room. It is a huge beast that looks something like a large printer. There is a small screen, which is currently off. -- You press the red power button next to the screen, and a loading screen pops up. The machine begins whirring loudly. When it finishes booting, the screen displays ""Insert sample"". -- You can put anything in your inventory into this machine, while it is on, by right-clicking on the item. -- What would you like to do next? --
  1. Examine the cabinets
  2. Read the book
  3. Check on the battery

The five cabinets above the counter are made of polished wood, with brass handles. You open the one on the left, and see rows and rows of vials. Each vial is labeled in careful handwriting. Some contain powders; other, liquids. On the bottom row is a bunch of metal canisters, also labeled. The next two cabinets down the row are also filled with vials. -- You open another cabinet, and see a whole bunch of empty glassware, spoons, eyedroppers, and a large scale. -- You open the rightmost cabinet. This one appears to be a small library of sorts - it is stocked with all sorts of books. -- What would you like to do? --
  1. Examine the machine on the table
  2. Read the book on the counter
  3. Check on the battery

When you get closer to the book, you see it isn't really a bound book, more like a looseleaf collection of papers held in a worn leather sheath. -- You open it up, and see the first page appears to be lab notes for some sort of experiment creating a chemical called hydorcortisone. The next page appears to also be lab notes, on how to make amoxicillin. -- After looking at the next few pages, which are all similar, you can tell this book is the lab notes of some chemist, on how to create all sorts of chemicals. -- What do you do next? --
  1. Examine the machine on the table
  2. Examine the cabinets
  3. Check on the battery

You take a short nap.
--
You wake up feeling refreshed.
<script>playerHP=maxHP</script>
--
Type anything to continue.

After waiting for a while, you head back to the battery, and carefully remove it from the wires. -- You put the battery back into the stun gun, and fire the stun gun at the wall. -- An arc of electricity shoots out of the stun gun and hits the wall. However, when you try to fire it again, it says the battery is low...again. -- What do you do next? --
  1. Try that again...but let it charge for longer
  2. Find some other way to charge the battery

After hunting around the lab a little bit, you find a little green box with a screen on it, labeled "Mini Combustor". It has some wires sticking out of it, and you find the wire that plugs into your stun gun. -- You press the "on" button on the reactor, and the screen comes to life. It displays "Please insert flammable material into back". -- When you turn the reactor over, you see a panel you can open up and dump something flammable in. -- What do you do next? --
  1. Look for something flammable
  2. Try the lab setup again

You look around some more, and find a box of pure carbon by the door. That seems like a good fuel for the mini combustor, and hopefully it can charge up the stun gun's battery.
--
But how much carbon do you add? Too much, and the battery might be fried. Too little, and it won't charge.
--
You find a book in the cabinet labeled "Data", and it says that carbon produces \(6.53 \times 10^{-19} J\) per atom burned.
--
If your battery needs \(14400 J\) to be fully charged, how many molecules of octane do you need to burn? Express your answer in scientific notation. For example, if your answer is \(2 \times 10^{-5}\), type '2E-5'.

That's right!
--
But counting that many  is not feasible, and besides you can't count individual atoms - they are too small.
--
What you can measure, however, is mass (using the scale in the cabinet), so now you need to find how many grams of carbon you need.
--
Looking at the periodic table, you notice the decimal beneath each element name is labeled the "atomic mass" of the atom - the mass of each atom in atomic mass units (amu).
--
Consulting the data book once more, you see that both protons and neutrons have a mass of 1 amu, but electrons have such a small mass they aren't counted.
--
So if that is the case, how many grams of carbon should you add to the reactor? (1 g = \(6.022 \times 10^23\) amu)
--
Don't express your answer in scientific notation, and to 3 significant figures.
narrative_nodes.hint: What is the mass of each carbon atom in amu? How many carbon atoms do you need? Then, convert amu to g.

narrative_nodes.text:
You walk to the cabinet and take out the scale. Then, you carefully measure 0.440 g of carbon.
--
You add this to the combustor, and close the panel. The combustor suddenly begins vibrating extremely violently, and you hear a hissing noise.
--
After a few seconds, the combustor abruptly stops.
--
You check the stun gun, but the battery is only charged to 99%.
--
As you check over your work, you discover that you assumed carbon had an atomic mass of 12 amu.
--
But the periodic table disagrees. What is the atomic mass of carbon on the periodic table?

Uh oh!
--
You decide to throw a sample of carbon into the identifier machine to settle the matter.
--
<script>pickup("carbon")</script>
Right click on the carbon in your inventory to throw it into the machine.
--
Type anything to continue.

Wait what?
--
But the label on the box of carbon says it is 100% pure carbon...
--
The second item, carbon-13, shouldn't be there. It has an atomic mass of 13 amu, but the box claims it is still carbon - so it must have 6 protons, or else it wouldn't be carbon. So how many neutrons does it have?

That's right! -- Carbon-12 and carbon-13, since they have different numbers of neutrons but are still carbon, are called isotopes of carbon. -- But this is not helpful for figuring out how many grams of carbon you need to put in the combustor. If some carbon atoms have atomic mass 12, and others 13, how do you figure out the mass of atoms needed? -- The trick is to use the average atomic mass of the carbon atoms - which is the weird decimal number 12.011 shown on the periodic table. -- The idea is that normally, you have so many atoms that the average mass of the atoms is pretty much constant, and you can use that to figure out how much a certain number of carbon atoms weigh. -- Let's see why the average mass of carbon atoms is 12.011. -- If you have 1000 atoms, on average, how many normal carbon-12 atoms are there? (Remember, carbon mainly exists as carbon-12 and carbon-13) Since your answer is less than 1000, don't express it in scientific notation.
That's right! How many carbon-13 atoms are there?
So what is the total mass of all the atoms in amu?
narrative_nodes.hint: Each carbon-12 atom weighs 12 amu, and each carbon-13 atom weighs 13 amu.

narrative_nodes.text:
Nice!
--
What is the average mass of the carbon atoms?

Great job!
--
Now you see where the weird decimal number came from, and hence why your stun gun's battery only charged to 99%.
--
So, using the more accurate average weight of a carbon atom, how much carbon do you need to add to the combustor (in g)? Remember, you need 2.21E22 carbon atoms. Since your answer should be greater than 0.001, don't express your answer in scientific notation.
narrative_nodes.hint: What is the mass of each carbon atom in amu? How many carbon atoms do you need? Then, convert amu to g.

narrative_nodes.text:
You add 0.441 g of carbon to the combustor.
--
Once again, the combustor shakes violently for a few seconds, hissing, before it stops.
--
This time when you check your stun gun, it is fully charged.
--
Nice job!
--
Type anything to continue.

You're getting kind of hungry. <script>DEX-=5; CON-=5;</script>
--
Some sugar would be nice, since it gives you energy.
--
You look through the lab for something sweet, but you only find two white powders. You know one of them is sugar and the other is salt.
--
Your throat is also really dry, so it probably wouldn't be the best idea to eat salt.
--
How could you tell them apart? You remember that some things dissolve in water, while others don't. Maybe you could use this to distinguish salt and sugar?
--
Let's try it out. <script>currentlab="saltvsugar"; pickup("Powder #1"); pickup("Powder #2");</script>Type "launch lab" to launch the lab workspace.
--
After you open the lab, type anything to continue.
Try putting the powders in the beakers. What happened?

Oh dear. It looks like both powders dissolve... -- You accidentally knock over the electricity thing, and the wire and lightbulb fall into one of the solutions (#1), along with a battery. Suddenly, the lightbulb lights up! -- So does this solution conduct electricity? --
  1. Yes
  2. No

You're right! -- Since solution #1 conducts electricity, it must have a bunch of positive and negative particles floating around. -- Curious, you pick up the lightbulb, wire, and battery, and throw them into the other solution (#2). However, the lightbulb doesn't light up. -- So does solution #2 have positive and negative bits floating around? --
  1. Yes
  2. No

Yep! -- Hmmm...if only you could figure out which solution (salt or sugar) can conduct electricity... -- Salt and sugar are both examples of molecules, which are groups of atoms stuck together. Molecules have different types, depending on which atoms are stuck together and how. Each type is called a compound. -- Compounds can be written using their chemical formulas - which act as kind of an ingredients list for what the molecule contains. For example, salt is made of sodium and chlorine atoms. Sodium's symbol is Na, and chlorine's symbol is Cl, so the formula for salt is "NaCl". -- So if a molecule is made of one carbon atom and one oxygen atom, what is its chemical formula?

Nice! -- When you flip through the book of compounds, you discover a picture of a salt molecule. One end of a salt molecule is marked positive, and the other end is marked negative. However, there is no such marking on the picture of a sugar molecule. Maybe this is why one conducts electricity and the other doesn't? -- You should probably check out to see if water is similar. You know water is made of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom, but you can't find "HHO" in the book. -- After flipping through the book some more, you find water - which is labeled "\{\ce{H_2O}\)". -- Ohh....so if there are two hydrogen atoms in the molecule, you write a little "2" next to the "H". -- The image of water shows one end of water is positive, and the other is negative. -- If one end of a salt molecule is positive and the other is negative, what happens when you put salt powder in water? --
  1. The positive ends of the water molecules are attracted to the positive ends of the salt molecules.
  2. The positive ends of the water molecules are attracted to the negative ends of the salt molecules.

Good job! -- So the water molecules basically pull apart the salt molecules. -- -- See? So does a salt solution have positive parts and negative parts floating around? --
  1. Yes
  2. No

That's right! -- If the sugar molecule doesn't have a positive and a negative end, can this happen? --
  1. Yes
  2. No

Sugar molecules themselves aren't broken, so when sugar dissolves in water, the individual sugar molecules just float around, so there's no charged bits, and so a sugar solution can't conduct electricity. -- By the way, molecules like salt and water that have a positive and a negative end are called "polar" molecules. Molecules like sugar that have no charged ends are called "nonpolar". -- If a salt molecule is made of sodium and chlorine, and is slightly positive around sodium, which atom pulls harder on electrons? --
  1. Na (sodium)
  2. Cl (chlorine)

Yep! -- Since Cl pulls harder, the area around it has more electrons, so it is negative. The area around Na has less electrons, and is positive, so the molecule has a positive end and a negative end. -- Remember the orbitals you learned about earlier? How electrons that are farther away from the nuclues have more energy? -- Well, the group of electrons farthest from the nucleus are called the valence electrons, and they are part of the valence shell (the highest energy orbital). -- An atom is most stable, with the least energy, when its valence shell is full. -- Well, let's say a sodium atom has one electron in his valence shell. Does it want to get rid of this electron? --
  1. Yes
  2. No
Why not?

Hmmmm...consider which is easier for Na: lose its electron or get a bunch more electrons to fill the valence shell. -- So, does the sodium atom want to get rid of his only valence electron? --
  1. Yes
  2. No

Yes! -- Cl is one electron short from a full valence shell. Does she want to get rid of her valence electrons? --
  1. Yep!
  2. Nope.

Hmmmm...consider which is easier for Cl: lose her electron or get a bunch more electrons to fill her valence shell. -- So, does Cl want to get rid of her valence electrons? --
  1. Yes
  2. No

You're right!
--
She desparately wants to get one more valence electron, so she will pull on any electron super hard.
--
Now, Na doesn't want his valence electron, and is super happy to give it away.
--
What do you think will happen?

Yep!
--
Now, Na just lost an electron. Is he 'positively charged' or 'negatively charged'?

Nice.
--
Cl just got an electron. Is she 'positively charged' or 'negatively charged'?

So if Na is positively charged and Cl is negatively charged, what will happen? --
  1. Nothing
  2. They will be attracted
  3. They will be repelled
narrative_nodes.hint: Remember that atoms are basically tiny magnets, and opposites attract...

narrative_nodes.text: That's right! -- The sodium and chlorine atoms will in fact be so attracted that they form a bond, called an ionic bond. -- Molecules are held together by bonds like these. -- This really only works if one atom is super willing to get rid of an electron and another is really desparate for an electron, like in salt. -- However, sugar is made of carbons, hydrogens, and oxygens. Carbon and oxygen pull with about the same strength. -- Will carbon and oxygen form an ionic bond? Type 'yes' or 'no'.
narrative_nodes.hint: Find carbon and oxygen on the periodic table. Is one of them willing to give away an electron, and is one of them desparate for an electron?

narrative_nodes.text:
You're learning really fast!
--
So that poses a problem. So far, we haven't seen a way for carbon and oxygen to bond, since neither of them is willing to give away electrons.
--
But carbon dioxide is a molecule made of carbon bonded to two oxygens. So what do you think happens?

Well, as it turns out, if neither atom pulls on the electrons much more than the other, the two atoms end up sharing.
--
Then, both atoms can have a full shell - kinda. It's glitching the system, pretty much - both atoms consider the electrons to be their own, so both can get a full shell, so both are happy!
--
In this case, do carbon and oxygen form a covalent bond? Type 'yes' or 'no'.

Nice job! -- Since neither oxygen nor carbon is willing to give up an electron, they end up sharing some of their electrons. -- In the case of carbon dioxide, the oxygen on the left shares two of its electrons with the carbon. The carbon also shares two of its own electrons, so in total, the carbon and oxygen share four electrons. -- How many pairs of electrons do each oxygen and carbon share?

Thus, the oxygen and carbon share two pairs of electrons, so the bond is a double bond. Remember, this bond is also covalent! -- If two atoms share one pair of electrons, the bond is a single bond. If two atoms share three pairs of electrons, the bond is called a triple bond. A quadruple bond is pretty much unheard of. -- Here's a tough question: In \(\ce{Cl_2}\), is the bond between the two chlorines 'ionic' or 'covalent'? If it is covalent, is the bond 'single' or 'double'? Type only one word.
narrative_nodes.hint: First, find chlorine on the periodic table. How many valence electrons does each chlorine have? Is the bond ionic or covalent? If it is covalent, how many electrons should each chlorine contribute so that they can share and both have full shells?

narrative_nodes.text: You're right! Since the chlorine atoms are equally strong, they will share the electrons in the middle. So neither is slightly positive or slightly negative. -- This is called a nonpolar covalent bond. -- If oxygen is much stronger than carbon, is the C-O bond 'polar covalent' or 'nonpolar covalent'?

Yep. Something similar happens with carbon and hydrogen, and oxygen and hydrogen. So at the end of the day, sugar is held together by only covalent bonds.
--
But some of those bonds are polar covalent...so wouldn't sugar still have a positive and negative end?
--
No, because sugar has a special shape that kind of balances everything out, so it doesn't have a positive and negative end, and so it doesn't get ripped apart by water.
--
So that's why the salt solution conducts electricity, but the sugar solution doesn't.
--
Go ahead and right click on the sugar in your inventory - you deserve it.
--
Remember, Powder #1 conducts electricity in water...but Powder #2 doesn't.
--
By the way, if you ever want to get rid of something in your inventory, just type "drop" and then the name.
--
Type anything to continue.

Now that you're all ready to continue trying to get out of this weird lab, you look for another door. -- You see another door. What would you like to do? --
  1. Try to carve a hole in the door with your stun gun
  2. Try to use the magnet trick you used with the first door
  3. Look around for a key
  4. Try to force the door open

Sturdy though the door might be, nothing can stand up to your stun gun!
--
You start to carve a hole in the door - and then your stun gun runs out of battery...again.
--
Unfortunately, you can't find any more carbon lying around. However, you do find some a lot of things in the cabinet that contain carbon, like some methane, \(\ce{CH_4}\).
--
If you burn methane, you end up with pure carbon - which is a black powder.
--
You remember from earlier that you need 0.441 g of carbon to fully charge the stun gun. So all that's left is to figure out how much methane you need...
--
To do this, you could first figure out what percent of the mass of methane is carbon, and then you can find out how much methane you need.
--
So, what's the mass of the carbon atom(s) in one molecule of methane, in amu?
narrative_nodes.hint: Find the mass of each carbon atom, and find how many carbon atoms there are in methane.
narrative_nodes.hint2: Look at the chemical formula of methane, \(\ce{CH_4}\)

narrative_nodes.text: You quickly find some magnets and get to work.

You look around the lab for a key. You find three keys, and try them on the door...but none of them work. -- What would you like to try next? --
  1. Try to carve a hole in the door
  2. Try to open the door with magnets
  3. Try to force the door open
This door looks much sturdier than the previous ones...

Wow...
--
By the way, the chance of you doing that successfully was pretty much 0...
--
But you are really strong!
--
The door slowly creaks open.
--
Type anything to continue.

Unfortunately, although you try your best, the door does not budge...even a little. -- What would you like to try next? --
  1. Try to carve a hole in the door
  2. Try to open the door with magnets
  3. Look for a key

Wow...
--
By the way, the chance of you doing that successfully was pretty much 0...
--
But you are really good at using magnets.
--
The door slowly creaks open.
--
Type anything to continue.

Unfortunately, as much as you move the magnet around, you don't hear any clicks. The door is too thick for this to work. -- What would you like to try next? --
  1. Try to carve a hole in the door
  2. Look for a key
  3. Try to force the door open

Yep.
--
What's the mass of one molecule of methane?
narrative_nodes.hint: Find the mass of each carbon atom and each hydrogen atom in amu.
narrative_nodes.hint2: If you know the mass of each carbon atom, and you know the mass of each hydrogen atom, you can find the mass of methane, which is just 1 carbon atom and 4 hydrogen atoms.

narrative_nodes.text: So what percentage of the mass of methane is from carbon? Express your answer as a pecent to 5 significant digits.

That's right!
--
So if you need 0.441 g of carbon, how many grams of methane do you need? Assume the mass percent of methane is 74.868%.

Nice job. -- You rifle through the cabinets until you find the canister labeled "methane". However, in your haste to put the gas into the mini-combustor, you lose most of it and only end up putting 0.5 g of methane into the combustor. -- You look for another canister of methane gas, but only find a canister with a label that starts with an m but then is smudged. This could be methane. -- What would you like to do? --
  1. Throw the gas into the machine
  2. Put the gas into the combustor anyway

You put the gas into the combustor, and turn it on.
--
The combustor sputters a little bit.
--
The stun gun's battery is only charged to 90%, so that gas must not have been methane. What was it?
--
Throw the gas into the machine to find out!
--
Type anything once you are done.
Try it out! Throw the gas into the machine by right clicking on it, and then see what happens. Type anything once you are done.

Well, the machine couldn't identify the gas, but it could tell us the mass composition. So we can figure out the compound for ourselves.
--
The easiest way to do this is to assume there are 100 grams of the gas - that's just a nice number to work with. You could pick any number you wanted.
--
So how many grams of carbon are there?

That's right! -- Now we need to figure out how many carbon atoms there are... but there are a lot...so let's introduce the mole. -- You know how you buy eggs by the dozen? Well, a mole is similar to a dozen. One mole of something is defined as \(6.022 \times 10^{23}\) of that thing. That number is known as Avadrago's number, abbreviated \(N_A\). So a mole of eggs would be \(6.022 \times 10^{23}\) eggs, and so on so forth. -- Normally, that number is so big we don't really use it, but when we talk about atoms, that is really useful. -- Now why such a seemingly random number? Well, as it turns out, \(6.022 \times 10^{23}\) amu is 1 gram. That means the little decimal underneath each element symbol on the periodic table is not only the atom's average mass in amu, but also the average mass of a mole of those atoms, in grams. So, 1 atom of carbon has a mass of 12.011 amu, and 1 mole of carbon atoms has a mass of 12.011 g. -- So how many moles of carbon are in the 100 g of gas?

That's right!
--
Repeating the calculations, how many moles of hydrogen are in the 100 g of gas?

Yep.
--
How many moles of fluorine are in the 100 g of gas?

Nice!
--
Hey, did you notice something? There are an equal number of moles of carbon and fluorine.
--
So the mystery gas has an equal number of carbon atoms and fluorine atoms per mole.
--
What's the ratio of hydrogen atoms to carbon atoms? Express your answer as a ratio of whole numbers (eg 1:1)

Good job.
--
So what's the final chemical formula of the gas? For example, if it were \(\ce{H_2O}\), type 'H_2O'
--
Put the carbon first, then the hydrogens, then the fluorines.

This mystery gas is \(\ce{CH_3F\}, which is methyl fluoride - definitely not methane.
--
Whew! Luckily, though, you find some extra methane in some corner of the closet.
--
You charge up the battery of the stun gun, and proceed to finish carving a hole in the door.
--
Several smoky minutes later, a piece of the door falls away, and you step through to the room outside.
--
Type anything to continue.

You step into a dim courtyard, the last rays of sunset casting everything in a pink and purple glow. -- The courtyard is paved with concrete, but a marble section in the center hosts a bronze statue, atop a marble pedestal. The statue is of a hand, palm upward. -- The buildings around you, upon closer inspection, all look to be abandoned. The entire complex is eerily silent. -- Suddenly, you hear a buzz, and see a swarm of bugs flying toward you. You hurry back into the lab, and the bugs don't seem to follow. When they reach the entrance you carved in the door, the cloud abruptly stops and flies away. -- -- Your bug bites begin to itch, and you notice several of them have begun to swell up. -- What would you like to do next? --
  1. Heal the bug bites
  2. Put on one of the protective suits and go back out
  3. Check out the statue

You vaguely remember something in the book - a compound called "sodium bicarbonate" that could help with the itching.
--
You look throught the book again, and discover the following thing written under "Production:"
--
\[\ce{NaOH (aq) + CO_2 (g) -> NaHCO_3 (g)}\]
--
What does that mean?
--
Well, considering it's written under "Production", it must be a recipe of sorts for how to make sodium bicarbonate (\(\ce{NaHCO_3}\)). The arrow probably means the stuff on the left forms the stuff on the right, sodium bicarbonate.
--
So you're probably going to need some \(\ce{NaOH}\) and some \(\ce{CO_2}\). Luckily, you find some in the cabinets. <script>currentlab="baking soda"</script>Let's open up the lab workspace and try it out!
--
Type anything once you have made baking soda.

items.name: Polyvinyl Chloride:
items.use: Building material, plastic bottles, packaging, bank or membership cards

items.name: Polyvinyl Chloride:
items.use: Building material, plastic bottles, packaging, bank or membership cards
